faqs.question: Why can't I just set my alarm for 5am starting tomorrow?
faqs.answer: Your circadian rhythm can only shift 15 minutes every 2-3 days safely. Jumping from 9am to 5am (4-hour shock) fights biology—you'll feel exhausted, brain foggy, and quit within days. Progressive 15-min shifts over 66 days = sustainable adaptation. Your body actually adjusts instead of being tortured awake.

faqs.question: I go to bed earlier but still can't wake up. Why?
faqs.answer: Going to bed earlier doesn't reset circadian rhythm automatically. Your body's melatonin cycle is trained for late wake. You lie awake or sleep poorly. Solution: Train wake time progressively (15-min shifts), THEN bedtime naturally adjusts earlier after 2-3 weeks. Circadian rhythm adapts from wake time, not bed time.

faqs.question: How do I overcome sleep inertia (feeling groggy when alarm goes off)?
faqs.answer: Sleep inertia lasts 30-90 min. Combat it: 1) Cold water on face immediately (activates alertness), 2) Bright light exposure (stops melatonin), 3) Movement (pushups, walk), 4) Exciting morning routine (gives reason to get up). NooLife's morning tasks provide structure when willpower is zero.

faqs.question: What if I'm just 'not a morning person'?
faqs.answer: Morning person vs night owl is 50% biology, 50% habit. Biology (chronotype) can shift 1-2 hours with training. Habit (circadian rhythm) is 100% trainable. Most 'night owls' are actually smartphone-addicted late sleepers. 66 days of progressive wake shifts + morning routine = you become morning person. Identity follows behavior.

faqs.question: How long before waking early feels natural?
